pages.text: Silvanerpeton miripedes comes from the lower Carboniferous, with fossils being found in the East Kirkton Quarry, Scotland (United Kingdom). It is a small reptiliomorph, growing up to 40 cm in length. The discovery of its fossil material was important, as it comes from 'Romer's Gap', a gap in the fossil record of tetrapods, which helped to 'close the gap'.

The generic name derives from the name 'Silvanus', the Roman God of Woods; and the Greek word 'herpeton', to mean 'creeping'. The specific name derives from the Latin words 'mirus', to mean 'wonderful': and 'pedes', to mean 'feet'.
